Everybody has their

you seem to be at the

586.27.text:

592.35.text:
I was born and raised

594.23.text:

597.89.text:
by the Americans, and freed

So we were so enamored

615.17.text:

618.59.text:
of all my relatives, starting

621.77.text:

my voice at such a young age,

631.21.text:
But like every child,
and especially-- I'm

635.53.text:
making a stereotype, but a
large majority of teenage girls

642.69.text:
In high school, I went

644.82.text:
I was 14, crying

646.73.text: also went to the same school.

647.94.text:
She was three years

649.77.text:

652.18.text:

654.95.text:

658.62.text:

660.36.text: And went on and on and on.

662.35.text:
An hour later, my sister, who
was three years older-- at 17,

665.83.text:
very, very wise--
said to me, we just

668.86.text: spent an hour talking about you.

673.25.text:
So obviously, a
majority of your brain

679.24.text:
What makes you think anybody
else thinks about you?

689.63.text:
They've got all other

693.06.text:
We spent this entire hour, 90%
of the time, talking about you.

697.64.text:
Other people are the same

704.62.text:
Fast forward, when
I get to college--

706.42.text:
I went to Mount Holyoke
College, an all women's college.

711.55.text: I went to a small liberal arts.

713.44.text:
But still, I was an immigrant,

716.97.text:
And I remember, at my very
first Asian American meeting,

721.58.text:
I raised my hand

725.06.text:
I was shaking, and my whole

737.10.text: What was going on in my brain?

739.39.text:
Where was all this

744.29.text:
I pose those things
because I think

745.75.text:
so many people have their

749.26.text:
of things that
are going through,

750.63.text:
whatever-- it's their
upbringing, whatever baggage,

754.93.text:
But there is an opportunity
to reprogram your brain.

757.43.text:
In my adulthood, I decided
to go on this journey.

762.24.text: I call it the me, you, we.

765.24.text:
I haven't written
a book about it.

767.66.text:
There's not any
marketing speak there.

769.50.text:
But it's called the
journey of me, you, we.

I'm going to go through

773.98.text:
But before I do that, I

776.67.text:
a heads up-- that after I

780.42.text:
you, we, I want

781.91.text:
up here, to share for one minute

788.13.text:
So think about it for a second,

792.22.text:
What is this journey
of me, you, we?

795.19.text:
The first part of me
is very narcissistic.

804.00.text:
You ask yourself, whether it's
in a professional or personal

810.34.text:
What is it in that meeting
that made me talk that way?

814.92.text:
What point was I

817.41.text:
Was I trying to
be a team player,

819.00.text:
or was I trying to shine

822.58.text:

825.78.text:
did you inspire
or did you impress

830.13.text:
Because at the end of the
day, what is it that matters?

833.04.text:
What are those
triggers that we have?

834.71.text:
And I'm talking about something
here in a professional setting,

837.83.text: What are my triggers at home?

840.01.text:
What is it that makes
me fly off the handle?

844.00.text:
What is it that makes me
passive, and not engaged?

848.00.text:
You actually have
to invest to get

849.80.text:
to the second phase,
of the you phase.

853.93.text:
Because the you phase
is all about leadership.

856.35.text:
It's focusing on
others-- not me, but you.

860.04.text: How do I focus on you?

861.52.text:
How can I ever focus
on you if I spend

863.73.text:
90% of my brain
thinking about me?

870.26.text:
How are you going
to run the meeting

871.92.text:
to focus on the strategy,
the content, the body

875.39.text:
language, the eye contact,
the subliminal messages that

879.70.text:
are being sent around to
everybody in the room?

881.72.text:
How are you running
that meeting if you're

884.63.text:
spending 90% of your brain
focused on the insecurity of,

887.91.text: am I saying the right thing?

889.50.text:
If I said this thing,
how am I being perceived?

895.05.text:
How could you get
to that journey

897.94.text:
of being a leader that focuses
on others if you're still

901.87.text:
grappling with so many
things related to you?

906.71.text:
So you have to invest
in that self-awareness.

912.88.text: And I've done that quite a bit.

914.17.text:
I also very much
encourage meditation.

917.92.text:
So it focuses a lot on
controlling your brain.

923.06.text:
There's a great Buddhist
monk-- a modern book called

930.42.text:
It makes me pause, take a

934.30.text:
what is it that's going
through in my brain?

937.23.text:
Is it the reality
of the situation,

939.00.text: or is it just my own stuff?

941.60.text: So that I can focus on you.

945.88.text:
Another advice I
give-- and I often

948.37.text:
give this to
management team members

950.29.text:
who will come and relate a
story to me of something that's

953.21.text:
difficult that's going
on in the company.

956.70.text:
And I will pause,
and say, let's go

959.08.text:
through-- I listen to
the whole story-- I said,

961.04.text:
let's go through
that again, but now,

962.76.text:
let's remove you
from the equation.

965.71.text:
Let's pretend you
weren't even part

968.20.text:
of the equation of
what happened there.

971.69.text:
Let's just focus
on the employee,

974.55.text:
and let's repeat
exactly what happened.

976.56.text:
And the story fundamentally
shifts, and the thinking

979.86.text:
shifts, in how we're going
to handle that situation.

982.76.text:
Because now, it's not about
the actual person relating

985.30.text:
this story, but it is about
the specific individual.

991.95.text:
And it's a powerful
thing to do that.

995.18.text:
Another mnemonic I
always give people

996.84.text:
is, when you're in a situation
and your body language starts

1001.58.text:
to shift, and your
heart rate, and this

1003.20.text:
is that investment
in you, and you

1004.62.text:
know your triggers-- what you
do is, you leave your body.

1010.74.text:
You leave your body
and watch yourself.

1014.66.text:
You literally watch
yourself, and say,

1016.69.text:
what is it that's
going on there?

1019.12.text:
What is the real conversation
that's happening?

1021.91.text:
What are we trying to get
across from each other,

1025.86.text: so I can go solve the problems?

1028.86.text:
Now let's talk
about the we part.

1031.40.text:
And by the way, going
from me to you to we,

1035.08.text: you can go back and forth.

1036.18.text: The we part is very Gandhi-like.

1038.37.text:
It's from what we call
success to significance.

1041.13.text:
It's a very long
journey in life.

1045.83.text:
You focus on the others, and
the people, and the lives

1049.80.text: The we part is a hard one.

1051.26.text:
Because how do you impact
the lives of people

1053.93.text:
that you don't come
into connection with?

1058.49.text:
How do you create an impact
and significance in the world?

1061.60.text:
How do you focus
on the broader we

1063.77.text:
of the things that you
decide to do in life

1065.69.text:
or what you represent
in terms of leadership?

1070.01.text:
It's a journey I'm still

1071.93.text:
And by the way, this
journey is not an easy one.

1073.93.text:
You go back and
forth constantly,

1075.43.text:
learning about yourself, being
better, as a leader, to others.

1080.19.text:
And then, at the
same time, how am I

1082.04.text:
making an impact in the
world, and what am I

1083.87.text:
doing every day that
makes a big difference?

1087.45.text:
I call that the
journey of me, you, we.

1090.59.text:
Now, I'm going to call

1093.48.text:

1095.86.text:
is the only way to

1108.90.text:
More importantly, where

1112.25.text:

1113.75.text:
because you did not want

1117.20.text:
So how are you going

1122.06.text:
It sounds pretty basic, but
how do you master your mind

1132.49.text:
It's just so much

1136.55.text:
And that was just

1138.05.text:
That was just asking for a
minute-long Katniss moment.

1140.01.text: It was your own personal story.

1147.09.text:
This is a technique-- I wish
that I came up with this,

1149.47.text:
but this, actually, I
just picked up at a spa.

1152.03.text:
I talked about the
narcissistic me.

1155.01.text:
It's called the
4-7-8, and it's one

1157.92.text:
of the most important business
techniques I try and teach

1165.74.text:
You hold for seven, and you
breathe out eight counts.

1172.11.text:
You do it in cycles
of four times.

1174.53.text:
Guaranteed, your heart
rate will come down,

1177.23.text:
and lizard brain will go away,
and you will get centered,

1180.08.text:
and you will focus on
whatever it is you're doing.

1184.61.text: I do it all the time.

1185.83.text:
I'm sitting here
right before I speak,

1187.75.text:
right before I have to go
on national television,

1190.19.text:
right before I run a
meeting, when I'm upset,

1194.73.text:
pissed off, driving in a car
and a driver is irritating me--

1200.33.text:
It's how do you create
that present in the moment

1202.76.text:
to stay focused and have
control of your brain.

1208.46.text:
That's one I picked
up at Canyon Ranch.

1212.52.text:
Why am I even talking about the
brain, and why does it matter,

1216.03.text:
and where is my

1218.45.text:
So now, let's come

1220.20.text: and describe me in a second.

1222.88.text:
Two things-- how did

1225.79.text:
that I described early

1236.59.text:

1240.15.text:

1244.69.text:

a lot of things

1246.47.text:
in me that I just

or not-- but why is

1258.97.text:
have to have the dishes

1265.60.text:
Why do I nag my teenage

1269.87.text:
He's giving this look
like, does it matter?

1272.00.text:
Because I've got to get
back in it tonight, anyways.

1277.04.text:
And my husband will come to
me, let's just enjoy the day.

1280.56.text: Why don't you let go of that?

1282.91.text:
And I found, psychologically,
it was probably

1286.11.text:
the same set of
triggers at work.

1288.90.text:
Because when I was asked to
be promoted to a director,

1293.40.text:
I felt like all these boxes
hadn't been checked yet.

1297.96.text:
So when I got offered to be a

1303.21.text: I don't know that I'm ready.
